title: Local theatre house
content:
![gavella](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526121351im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/27485.jpg)   
   
hi all,   
   
I did the logo for local theatre as a part of complete visual identity redesign.   
I'm stuck on the logotype that will go with logo, actually I'm unsure what font to choose for it.   
   
In this example above I used Adobe Garamond only as an example.   
I want to use serif face (but am open for san serif suggestions as well) for several reasons that I�ll try to address here...   
   
logo is made of continuous stroke of the same width, overall shape, if I may say so, has a abstract/geometric form which is 'broken', though with the 'ear' of lowercase letter "g",which gives it sort of organic (..yeah i know ;) ) feel .In the topmost picture you can see a sort of process how logo actually came to its final form. Anyway... to make contrast between logo and type, between geometric(logo) and organic(logotype) I choused serif face.   
I maybe totally wrong here but that�s why I'm here.   
   
If someone can recommend a serif face that has double storey "g" glyph, the one which has open bottom counter (for the lack of my knowledge in typographic terminology I included an example (bottom picture)).   
As I said so already, I'm open for any suggestions.   
   
thanks and sorry for my bad english.
author: mrfsrf

comments.content: Luka, I'm going to look up some sans faces with that kind of g. The singular weight of your mark could be complimented by a sans if it echoed the shape. Dan

Luka, I'm back. Take a look at these sans faces and see if any of them compliment your logo better. News Gothic Condensed, Trade Gothic Condensed (its squarer than News Gothic), Formata light Condensed, Optima, Agenda Light Condensed. You can find these faces at MyFonts to take a look. If you want something more unusual, take a look at Dyna Grotesk D Plain, Faber Eins/Zwei Normal, Pragma ND Light.

Hi Daniel,   
Tanks for feedback and great type suggestions.   
Soem of them are here in the picture below, few ones I liked the most are enclosed in rectangle.   
   
Really liked how good condensed versions works with logo ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526121351im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
   
thx   
   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526121351im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/27583.jpg)

Luka, I think your mark is pretty well done. I'd be interested to see how the top of the logo "g" would look if it were closed, like the speaking bubble in your first post.   
   
I'm having trouble seeing the reason for the red box. The "g" is a bit unbalanced inside of it and I don't know if it belongs. What do you think about eliminating the box and increasing the size of the "g" stroke?   
   
Of course, losing the box would make it much harder to incorporate the theatre name. Hm. One more thing�contrary to your thoughts, I don't really jive with the condensed type. Oh well. Perhaps I will get my eyes checked.   
   
Keep up the good work!

The openness of the g seems to match the logo best in Optima, and optima looks like one of the easier ones to read at the smaller size, but it has the most contrast.   
   
I like the curved l's in agenda, but I'm wondering if straight l's �parallel� the idea of the box better? With the g matching well though, it's a tough one to pass up!   
   
The bolder sans in the center column at the bottom (trade?) is looking pretty nice. I think the l's are being set too closely though (not sure how final, sorry). The spacing you have in optima seems to be more correct.   
   
None of those though have the exact g that you were looking for, with the lower bowl open. (But if you really like any of the ones you're working with, that's something you could make yourself.)   
   
However, John Sans, (although it isn't monoweight), has less contrast than optima, has an open-bowl g, and even has the organic ear on the g.

once again, thanks all for responses   
   
@Daniel Madden   
Without the red box there is danger of interpretation as "ggavella" (two g's in the row)   
so its function is to differentiate the logo from type.   
As you said it yourself, than it's much harder to   
incorporate theatre name.   
There will be lots of printed material which format is much wider than taller so there wouldn't be enough space for logo if type goes beneath it.   
   
   
@Brian   
   
I agree that optima is much better option, but I'm   
biased with this font, big part of market for cosmetic products has optima on its label.

Oh, I think Optima works in some ways, but the other examples work better, so it's not my favorite. I think it's contrast takes it out of the running, and it looks to feminine. I'm thinking that if there was a monoweight version of John sans, that would be perfect, or just to alter the g from either trade or news gothic.

Heyas Tiffany,   
   
thanks for suggestions, I like that second one with 'funky' ear.   
Here, I put it beside mark to see how well will   
they work. What's that font, btw.   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526121351im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/29/27694.jpg)
Luka, if you go with DynaGrotesk try making the ear on your illustration follow the ear on the g in gavella.

Personally, I'm more intrgigued by the presentation in the first post. Not so much the type, though it isn't bad, but the way you showcased the development of the symbol.   
   
If I were you, I would consider using all three elements in their logo. Without them, I just don't make the connection of the talk bubble. Also, illustrating the progression might imply the nature of what the theater company does -- presents stories.   
   
Just my 2 cents.

Tiffany those three names "Gradsko dramsko kazali�te" means "City drama theatre".   
   
Daniel thx, i will conmsider it.   
   
Sativo, thanks for nice comments, but I'm afraid logo is accepted as it is now.   
I also like that process myself, that's why I based my presentation on it.
